episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.384
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.384 --> 00:00:09.541
>> Hi, I'm Josh Marpet and
welcome to the Business for

3
00:00:09.541 --> 00:00:12.520
Technologists talk series
here at BizPro.tv.

4
00:00:12.520 --> 00:00:16.000
With me is Scott Lions,
we're the Chief Operating Officer and

5
00:00:16.000 --> 00:00:18.310
Chief Executive Officer of Red Lion.

6
00:00:18.310 --> 00:00:21.600
And we're gonna be talking about all sorts
of things about starting a business,

7
00:00:21.600 --> 00:00:23.570
running a business, and
eventually exiting a business.

8
00:00:23.570 --> 00:00:25.400
But first, let me tell you who we are.

9
00:00:25.400 --> 00:00:26.690
Scott, why don't you start?

10
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:28.090
>> Sure.
Thanks, Josh.

11
00:00:28.090 --> 00:00:34.190
I am the CEO of Red Lion, I'm a graduate
of the school of business hard knocks.

12
00:00:34.190 --> 00:00:41.860
I have assisted in multiple B-Side events,
both as a goon and as a regular attendee.

13
00:00:41.860 --> 00:00:46.260
I am part of the peer review board for

14
00:00:46.260 --> 00:00:50.200
SNAC, which is a journal of information
security, which is coming out later.

15
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:52.930
I do hold certifications
in information security.

16
00:00:52.930 --> 00:00:54.040
I won't say which.

17
00:00:54.040 --> 00:00:57.129
And my real passions are people and
business.

18
00:00:58.740 --> 00:01:00.300
>> And I'm Josh Marpet.

19
00:01:00.300 --> 00:01:01.480
I'm the CO of Red Lion.

20
00:01:02.600 --> 00:01:04.260
I've been around the block more than once.

21
00:01:04.260 --> 00:01:06.766
I'm an ex-cop, an ex-fireman,
an ex-horse dentist.

22
00:01:06.766 --> 00:01:08.120
That's not a joke, I swear.

23
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:10.099
I'm, let's see.

24
00:01:10.099 --> 00:01:14.089
Good lord, I'm a former board member
of Hackers for Charity, Las Vegas,

25
00:01:14.089 --> 00:01:17.180
the Cloud Security Alliance,
Delaware Valley.

26
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:20.055
I'm one of the primary organizers
of security B-Sides Delaware.

27
00:01:20.055 --> 00:01:23.840
Scott and I run multiple companies and
occasionally, we sleep.

28
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:25.390
it's an amazing thing.

29
00:01:25.390 --> 00:01:28.316
So let's talk about Business for
Technology.

30
00:01:28.316 --> 00:01:29.623
The Business for

31
00:01:29.623 --> 00:01:34.210
Technologists series is literally about
if you're a technologist with an idea,

32
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:39.060
a product, a prototype or whatever but
I wanna bring it to commercial success.

33
00:01:39.060 --> 00:01:42.670
How do I get there, and
what obstacles am I gonna see on the way?

34
00:01:42.670 --> 00:01:45.082
Scott, why don't you talk about
the talks we are going to be giving.

35
00:01:45.082 --> 00:01:45.790
>> Sure thing.

36
00:01:45.790 --> 00:01:50.670
So, in this series, what we're
really trying to do is to say here's

37
00:01:50.670 --> 00:01:54.530
how you start a business,
to here's how you end the business.

38
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:58.890
So we want to cover everything from
product creation, to sales management,

39
00:01:58.890 --> 00:01:59.969
to business development.

40
00:02:01.310 --> 00:02:04.800
And everything in between, talking about
the pitfalls, what to look out for,

41
00:02:04.800 --> 00:02:09.250
how to move things forward and
really understand how to make the deal.

42
00:02:09.250 --> 00:02:12.792
>> Yeah,
basically it's a compilation of wisdom and

43
00:02:12.792 --> 00:02:16.100
failures [LAUGH] that we have had and
problems that we've encountered.

44
00:02:16.100 --> 00:02:17.940
Remember, you learn from failure.

45
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:21.460
Well, I'd prefer that you learn from
our failures rather than your own.

46
00:02:21.460 --> 00:02:24.820
This is a way for you to get an idea
of what pitfalls are in the way.

47
00:02:24.820 --> 00:02:28.930
Everything from I've got an idea, how much
money do I need to bring it to creation,

48
00:02:28.930 --> 00:02:32.300
to fulfillment, to a prototype,
to a minimum viable product?

49
00:02:32.300 --> 00:02:33.270
What do I need to do?

50
00:02:33.270 --> 00:02:34.880
How do I get validation?

51
00:02:34.880 --> 00:02:38.840
Everything from how do I start it,
what's the paperwork I need to do it,

52
00:02:38.840 --> 00:02:42.820
to what kind of ways can I get out of this
business, how do I exit hopefully with

53
00:02:42.820 --> 00:02:46.390
a lot of money in my pocket and
a successful entrepreneurship on my belt?

54
00:02:47.420 --> 00:02:49.590
In that fashion,
we're gonna go through a series of talks,

55
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:51.510
talking about all these different stages.

56
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:54.610
Now there is a series of six
talks that are the primary core

57
00:02:54.610 --> 00:02:57.877
of the B-for-T curricula, but
there's gonna be additional talks as well.

58
00:02:57.877 --> 00:02:59.357
Things about that business paperwork.

59
00:02:59.357 --> 00:03:03.080
Short talks about what types of tools
you can use for a very low cost.

60
00:03:03.080 --> 00:03:06.510
There's going to be talks about
what type of exits there are and

61
00:03:06.510 --> 00:03:08.290
all sorts of different topics.

62
00:03:08.290 --> 00:03:12.100
I think it's gonna be a fantastic time and
we hope you'll enjoy it with us.

63
00:03:12.100 --> 00:03:13.070
Scott, anything else?

64
00:03:13.070 --> 00:03:15.400
>> Yeah, really for this series, Josh,

65
00:03:15.400 --> 00:03:17.890
what we want people to be
able to take away from this,

66
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:22.960
you as the viewer, is to be able to sit
back and say okay I have a product.

67
00:03:22.960 --> 00:03:25.640
I know where to go to put
my business together,

68
00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:27.790
and then how do I run the business?

69
00:03:27.790 --> 00:03:31.450
And that's the real meat
behind the takeaways for

70
00:03:31.450 --> 00:03:36.300
you as the viewer to be able to
understand business for technologists.

71
00:03:36.300 --> 00:03:38.730
>> Thank you,
I think that covers pretty much it.

72
00:03:38.730 --> 00:03:41.880
If you'd like to watch the series,
just click below and

73
00:03:41.880 --> 00:03:46.685
you can sign up with an account for
BizPro.tv or ITPro.tv and

74
00:03:46.685 --> 00:03:50.160
then you can watch the entire set of
videos from us as well as from all

75
00:03:50.160 --> 00:03:53.963
the other amazing content creators
here at BizPro, on ITPro.tv.

76
00:03:53.963 --> 00:03:55.334
Thank you.

77
00:03:55.334 --> 00:03:58.632
[SOUND]

episodes.description: The Technology is only worth 5 percent
episodes.title: The Technology is only worth 5 percent
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.108 --> 00:00:06.156
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.156 --> 00:00:09.823
Hi, and welcome to BizPro.TV's
The Technology is Only Worth 5%,

3
00:00:09.823 --> 00:00:14.170
the first in these series of lectures
about business for technologists.

4
00:00:14.170 --> 00:00:15.140
I'm Josh Marpet.

5
00:00:15.140 --> 00:00:16.493
This is Scott Lyons, and

6
00:00:16.493 --> 00:00:20.566
we're here from Red Lion to talk to
you about The Technology is Worth 5%.

7
00:00:20.566 --> 00:00:24.918
Now that whole talk came about when I
heard that sentence come out of a venture

8
00:00:24.918 --> 00:00:26.810
capitalist's mouth.

9
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:30.395
He said the technology is only worth 5%,
and I was stunned.

10
00:00:30.395 --> 00:00:32.190
I said, what do you mean?

11
00:00:32.190 --> 00:00:35.770
He said, well, when I go to buy a company,
I look at the team.

12
00:00:35.770 --> 00:00:37.370
I look at all the things
they have about them,

13
00:00:37.370 --> 00:00:41.240
their past track record, who they are,
what they've done, who they've been with.

14
00:00:41.240 --> 00:00:44.200
Who they know is actually more
important than the technology.

15
00:00:44.200 --> 00:00:48.531
The technology, 5% or so,
that's about all that matters to me.

16
00:00:48.531 --> 00:00:49.790
And that's shocked me.

17
00:00:49.790 --> 00:00:54.130
So Scott and I got together in order to
talk about it and well, let's get started.

18
00:00:54.130 --> 00:00:56.370
So Scott, why don't you just
talk to us about yourself?

19
00:00:56.370 --> 00:00:58.100
>> Sure thing, Josh, thank you.

20
00:00:58.100 --> 00:00:59.445
So hi, I'm Scott Lyons.

21
00:00:59.445 --> 00:01:01.867
I'm the CEO of Red Lion.

22
00:01:01.867 --> 00:01:05.483
I have been through the school
of business hard knocks.

23
00:01:05.483 --> 00:01:07.573
I've been in and
out of federal government.

24
00:01:07.573 --> 00:01:12.843
I've seen the good, the bad,
and the ugly of contracting.

25
00:01:12.843 --> 00:01:14.987
Had multiple failed businesses.

26
00:01:14.987 --> 00:01:19.530
Josh and I right now are in charge of Red
Lion which is going really, really well.

27
00:01:19.530 --> 00:01:22.090
My passion is people in business, though.

28
00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:26.860
And that's really, really important,
the human aspect of business.

29
00:01:26.860 --> 00:01:27.360
Josh?

30
00:01:28.700 --> 00:01:31.130
>> So hi, I'm Joshua Marpet, as I stated.

31
00:01:31.130 --> 00:01:32.680
I'm the COO of Red Lion.

32
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:35.992
Scott and I have been working
together now for God, about a year.

33
00:01:35.992 --> 00:01:38.776
I've been a startup CEO, an executive.

34
00:01:38.776 --> 00:01:42.132
I've spoken at everything around
the country that you can imagine in terms

35
00:01:42.132 --> 00:01:42.723
of InfoSec.

36
00:01:42.723 --> 00:01:47.180
And I graduated from Mach37 Cyber
Accelerator in Herndon, Virginia.

37
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:48.444
I've been around the block like I said.

38
00:01:48.444 --> 00:01:49.434
I'm an ex-cop,

39
00:01:49.434 --> 00:01:53.190
an ex-fireman, ex-blacksmith, although I
really wanna get back into blacksmithing.

40
00:01:53.190 --> 00:01:54.855
It's a lot of fun to actually
do things with your hands.

41
00:01:54.855 --> 00:01:57.810
>> [LAUGH]
>> I am one of the primary organizers of

42
00:01:57.810 --> 00:02:01.980
Security BSides Delaware, the biggest and
oldest BSides conference in Delaware.

43
00:02:01.980 --> 00:02:03.660
And occasionally, I get a nap in.

44
00:02:03.660 --> 00:02:07.916
[LAUGH] So let's get to work talking
about business for technology.

45
00:02:07.916 --> 00:02:12.395
>> So in this series, what we're really
trying to go over is everything from

46
00:02:12.395 --> 00:02:17.405
how to start a business to how to exit
the business and everything in between.

47
00:02:17.405 --> 00:02:19.815
Everything from biz dev,
to sales management,

48
00:02:19.815 --> 00:02:25.020
to product creation,
to actually running your company, right?

49
00:02:25.020 --> 00:02:29.855
So in this talk though,
we're focusing on tech is only 5%, right?

50
00:02:29.855 --> 00:02:35.565
So moving forward right down into
the agenda of today's talk, right?

51
00:02:35.565 --> 00:02:40.101
So we're gonna talk about,
what is the most important piece for

52
00:02:40.101 --> 00:02:43.293
astartup, what the cast
of characters is for

53
00:02:43.293 --> 00:02:47.730
an entrepreneurial web cycle setting,
yeah thanks.

54
00:02:47.730 --> 00:02:52.365
We wanna go into a little bit about
market validation, some investability,

55
00:02:52.365 --> 00:02:55.446
and then we really need to
get down to the decision.

56
00:02:55.446 --> 00:03:01.220
And the decision is one of the most key
markers for success in any business, Josh.

57
00:03:01.220 --> 00:03:03.770
>> So let's talk about what's
most important, all right?

58
00:03:03.770 --> 00:03:06.100
So you've got things like your
corporate administration.

59
00:03:06.100 --> 00:03:09.040
You've got fundraising, you've got
technology and corporate business.

60
00:03:09.040 --> 00:03:10.760
So what do those things mean?

61
00:03:10.760 --> 00:03:14.370
Well, look, when you start a business it's
not all, hey I'm gonna go build stuff.

62
00:03:14.370 --> 00:03:18.821
You're gonna be doing,
hey I've gotta do HR, god!

63
00:03:18.821 --> 00:03:19.738
But you've got to do it.

64
00:03:19.738 --> 00:03:21.103
You've got to get your EIN.

65
00:03:21.103 --> 00:03:23.151
You've got to get your
incorporation paper signed.

66
00:03:23.151 --> 00:03:26.206
You've got to get your licenses if
you need them for your state or for

67
00:03:26.206 --> 00:03:28.270
any states you wanna do business in.

68
00:03:28.270 --> 00:03:30.940
You've got to protect your
intellectual property, your IP.

69
00:03:30.940 --> 00:03:33.300
You've got to get your stock issued or
if you're an LLC,

70
00:03:33.300 --> 00:03:35.850
your percentages in
the company spread out.

71
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:38.700
You've gotta decide,
am I gonna be a government contractor?

72
00:03:38.700 --> 00:03:40.367
Because if you're a government contractor,
Scott,

73
00:03:40.367 --> 00:03:41.860
you're the expert on
government contracting.

74
00:03:41.860 --> 00:03:42.380
>> Mm-hm.

75
00:03:42.380 --> 00:03:44.940
>> What are the important pieces
of ownership of a business for

76
00:03:44.940 --> 00:03:45.890
government contracting?

77
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:50.690
>> So there are many different qualifiers
for government contracting, Josh, right?

78
00:03:50.690 --> 00:03:54.569
And some of those qualifiers
can be a woman-owned business,

79
00:03:54.569 --> 00:03:57.628
a small business, minority-owned business,

80
00:03:57.628 --> 00:04:02.640
an Alaskan native-owned business, and
a Hawaiian native-owned business.

81
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:05.530
That is something that we're going to
be going over in a different talk.

82
00:04:05.530 --> 00:04:08.430
But it is very important to understand,
when you're talking about

83
00:04:08.430 --> 00:04:12.950
corporate structure, how the business is
actually owned, run, operated, maintained,

84
00:04:12.950 --> 00:04:15.960
and moved forward
>> So let's go back to our slide.

85
00:04:15.960 --> 00:04:20.490
And you'll notice that in all
of these things, in all four

86
00:04:20.490 --> 00:04:24.590
categories of what's most important,
technology is just one of the four.

87
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:28.040
And it only has one thing in it, the idea.

88
00:04:28.040 --> 00:04:30.650
Everything else has multiple
pieces you've gotta worry about.

89
00:04:30.650 --> 00:04:31.710
How do you pay people?

90
00:04:31.710 --> 00:04:33.700
How do you talk to people?

91
00:04:33.700 --> 00:04:35.820
Who's running the office?

92
00:04:35.820 --> 00:04:37.120
Do you have to pay for Internet?

93
00:04:37.120 --> 00:04:39.010
Well, I mean normally, right?

94
00:04:39.010 --> 00:04:41.140
Even if it's at your house,
you gotta pay for internet.

95
00:04:41.140 --> 00:04:42.340
And if you pay for
Internet at your house, and

96
00:04:42.340 --> 00:04:43.590
you're running your
office out of your house,

97
00:04:43.590 --> 00:04:45.420
hey, you can actually do a tax deduction.

98
00:04:45.420 --> 00:04:46.420
But that's a later talk.

99
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:49.670
You've got to fundraise,
because while you're building this,

100
00:04:49.670 --> 00:04:52.270
you've got to have either a job or
some money to live off of.

101
00:04:52.270 --> 00:04:57.020
Because those magic things called rent and
mortgage, they don't pay themselves.

102
00:04:57.020 --> 00:05:00.560
>> Right, and
that even carries into the team,

103
00:05:00.560 --> 00:05:03.530
the implementation, what your sales are.

104
00:05:03.530 --> 00:05:07.150
Because let's face it,
sales are a big thing here, right?

105
00:05:07.150 --> 00:05:09.240
What type of marketing
you're using as well.

106
00:05:09.240 --> 00:05:14.429
So if you are going after VC funding,
VCs today, venture capitalists,

107
00:05:14.429 --> 00:05:18.271
are gonna say to you,
I wanna see your sales, right?

108
00:05:18.271 --> 00:05:19.777
I wanna see what your margins are.

109
00:05:19.777 --> 00:05:21.180
I wanna see what your profits are.

110
00:05:21.180 --> 00:05:25.590
I wanna see how much it costs to
make what your product is, right?

111
00:05:25.590 --> 00:05:26.800
>> Right.
>> And if you don't have sales,

112
00:05:26.800 --> 00:05:29.310
a lot of VCs are gonna
actually walk from you, right?

113
00:05:29.310 --> 00:05:31.050
>> Right.
>> That's no traction.

114
00:05:31.050 --> 00:05:33.000
And without traction,
you're not getting money.

115
00:05:33.000 --> 00:05:34.760
Its just that simple these days.

116
00:05:34.760 --> 00:05:36.460
So again, that's a later talk.

117
00:05:36.460 --> 00:05:38.900
But the point is out of all
these categories of things,

118
00:05:38.900 --> 00:05:43.610
the technology was only one and
that's tough.

119
00:05:43.610 --> 00:05:47.180
Because there's so many details
that aren't your actual technology,

120
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:48.970
that aren't your actual product.

121
00:05:48.970 --> 00:05:51.740
They're the marketing, they're the team,
they're everything else but

122
00:05:51.740 --> 00:05:52.630
it's not the product.

123
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:56.610
>> So before we go past all this,
Joshua, I wanna ask you something.

124
00:05:56.610 --> 00:06:03.390
Out of the eight items that we have listed
here, what would you consider to be

125
00:06:03.390 --> 00:06:08.690
the most important number one and
number two item for people to focus on?

126
00:06:08.690 --> 00:06:11.017
>> Okay, that's a great question.

127
00:06:11.017 --> 00:06:15.158
I will tell you that the number one item
that venture capitalists are looking for,

128
00:06:15.158 --> 00:06:18.350
and honestly, they're kind of
the important ones right now.

129
00:06:18.350 --> 00:06:21.210
Because you wanna decide if your company's
going to be a venture capital funded

130
00:06:21.210 --> 00:06:22.410
company or not.

131
00:06:22.410 --> 00:06:25.490
They're looking at the team and
they're looking at your sales.

132
00:06:25.490 --> 00:06:28.886
If you have a successfully exited
entrepreneur, that's a magic term,

133
00:06:28.886 --> 00:06:32.770
don't forget it, a successfully
exited entrepreneur on your team.

134
00:06:32.770 --> 00:06:35.458
If you have a team that has
proven sales track record,

135
00:06:35.458 --> 00:06:37.520
proven marketing track record.

136
00:06:37.520 --> 00:06:42.020
If you have a product that has actually
made sales and so you have traction.

137
00:06:42.020 --> 00:06:43.825
Wow, you've got a lot going for you.

138
00:06:43.825 --> 00:06:47.460
Notice not once there did I mention you
have a great technology, a great idea or

139
00:06:47.460 --> 00:06:48.390
a great prototype.

140
00:06:48.390 --> 00:06:50.250
>> Okay, okay, okay, so hold on,

141
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:56.180
you're telling me that you have to have
a successful entrepreneur on your team?

142
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:58.540
What is the key marker of that?

143
00:06:58.540 --> 00:06:59.566
And then we're gonna keep going.

144
00:06:59.566 --> 00:07:01.558
But I just wanna pull this out of you so

145
00:07:01.558 --> 00:07:05.930
that everybody who's watching this
understands what we understand.

146
00:07:05.930 --> 00:07:08.740
>> So a successfully exited
entrepreneur is somebody that is,

147
00:07:08.740 --> 00:07:10.290
I mean it's in the name.

148
00:07:10.290 --> 00:07:13.248
They've sold a company,
they've sold intellectual property,

149
00:07:13.248 --> 00:07:16.225
they've performed a liquidation event,
as it's known, okay.

150
00:07:16.225 --> 00:07:19.478
And they've either sold the intellectual
property to a another company,

151
00:07:19.478 --> 00:07:23.180
they've sold the entire company,
they've been acqui-hired, whatever.

your traction, your sales,

834

your marketing, your market,
your intellectual property, the risks,

835

all that kinda stuff.

836

Only one or
two questions is actually about the-

>> All right, so I have to interject here.

838

Let's boil this down to one question,
one question everybody can deal with.

839

Is it all worth it?

840

>> No.
[LAUGH]

841

>> No.

842

>> Not even close.

843
00:41:24.080 --> 00:41:26.080
It's a horrifyingly bad idea.

844
00:41:26.080 --> 00:41:27.060
Don't do it.

845
00:41:27.060 --> 00:41:28.210
No, I'm serious.

846

Don't do it, okay?

847
00:41:29.860 --> 00:41:34.372
You're not going to do this
unless you're an absolutely

848
00:41:34.372 --> 00:41:39.480
passionate person about this team,
this market, the risks.

849

Unless the competitors are so
bad that you know you can beat them,

850
00:41:42.952 --> 00:41:47.070
unless you've done a competitive
differentiator and measured all of that.

851
00:41:47.070 --> 00:41:50.266
You're not gonna do it unless
you absolutely know for

852

a fact that you can beat
everybody else on the marketplace.

853
00:41:53.827 --> 00:41:56.811
Or at least take enough of their business
away to make it worthwhile to the tune of

854
00:41:56.811 --> 00:41:59.070
millions and millions and
millions of dollars.

855
00:41:59.070 --> 00:42:02.290
You're not gonna do this unless you know
that you've got people backing you up who

856
00:42:02.290 --> 00:42:05.790
are just rock solid,
100% never gonna let you go.

857
00:42:05.790 --> 00:42:07.620
Never gonna let you, wait wrong song.

858
00:42:07.620 --> 00:42:09.520
>> Whoa whoa whoa time out, time out.

859

We can't do that on this show, okay?

860
00:42:11.320 --> 00:42:12.190
>> All right fine.

861
00:42:13.400 --> 00:42:16.940
But in all seriousness unless
you're absolutely obsessive and

862
00:42:16.940 --> 00:42:20.690
passionate about it, don't do it, okay?

863
00:42:20.690 --> 00:42:21.770
I'm not joking.

864
00:42:21.770 --> 00:42:24.520
This series is not to tell you
how you should be awesome and

865
00:42:24.520 --> 00:42:29.610
do a business everyday because frankly,
that's not a good idea.

866
00:42:29.610 --> 00:42:32.700
>> So
let's say that you have made the decision.

867
00:42:32.700 --> 00:42:35.710
That you are going to do it and
you say, you know what Josh and Scott?

868
00:42:35.710 --> 00:42:37.950
I have heard all of your malarkey.

869
00:42:37.950 --> 00:42:40.960
I've heard it all,
I know what I'm doing, okay?

870
00:42:42.902 --> 00:42:46.750
I've made the decision is to
start the business, all right?

871
00:42:46.750 --> 00:42:48.067
Notice how sad he sounds.

872
00:42:48.067 --> 00:42:49.950
Did you hear how sad he sounds?

873
00:42:49.950 --> 00:42:51.682
He's like okay,
I'm gonna go start a business.

874
00:42:51.682 --> 00:42:52.725
I suppose it's okay.

875
00:42:52.725 --> 00:42:53.866
>> I hope you're ready for no sleep.

876
00:42:53.866 --> 00:42:57.642
I really do, I really hope that you
are tried, true and prepared for

877
00:42:57.642 --> 00:42:59.040
absolutely zero sleep.

878
00:43:00.972 --> 00:43:05.030
>> But you know what,
if you're gonna do it, do it right.

879
00:43:05.030 --> 00:43:09.580
Either be a successfully exited
entrepreneur or be somebody that's failed.

880
00:43:09.580 --> 00:43:10.770
I'm not joking.

881
00:43:10.770 --> 00:43:14.400
Failure actually gives you a better
chance of succeeding the next time.

882
00:43:14.400 --> 00:43:16.700
Not much of a better chance,
but a better chance.

883
00:43:16.700 --> 00:43:19.270
And it gives you a heck of
a lot of learning experience.

884
00:43:19.270 --> 00:43:22.430
If you get that learning experience,
if you get the knowledge, that wow,

885
00:43:22.430 --> 00:43:24.200
I did this wrong the last time.

886
00:43:24.200 --> 00:43:25.920
I'm going to try something different.

887
00:43:25.920 --> 00:43:30.750
At the very least you're lessening your
chance of having the same problems

888
00:43:30.750 --> 00:43:33.750
that you did during your failure mode,
okay?

889
00:43:33.750 --> 00:43:36.530
You need to do this at least once.

890
00:43:36.530 --> 00:43:40.990
If you're gonna do it, do it,
and if you fail, don't give up.

891
00:43:40.990 --> 00:43:44.120
Every failure gives you a better
chance to succeed the next time.

892
00:43:44.120 --> 00:43:49.200
Now realistically, that just sounds like
I'm pushing you to mortgage your house and

893
00:43:49.200 --> 00:43:51.120
do 15 businesses in a row, and

894
00:43:51.120 --> 00:43:53.760
fail every time because I
might succeed the next time.

895
00:43:53.760 --> 00:43:55.570
Josh said so.

896
00:43:55.570 --> 00:43:57.690
I'm not, okay?

897
00:43:57.690 --> 00:43:59.020
Plan each and every single one.

898
00:43:59.020 --> 00:44:02.470
If it takes you years in between,
take years, that's fine.

899
00:44:02.470 --> 00:44:03.640
But do it the right way.

900
00:44:03.640 --> 00:44:07.190
If you're gonna do it, if you're bound and
determined, I'm gonna start a business and

901
00:44:07.190 --> 00:44:09.090
I'm gonna succeed, do it.

902
00:44:09.090 --> 00:44:11.640
And I respect that, and
I respect not doing it as well.

903
00:44:11.640 --> 00:44:14.160
Some people are risk averse and
don't want to.

904
00:44:14.160 --> 00:44:18.660
>> So get out there and if you really
want to do if you really want to try and

905
00:44:18.660 --> 00:44:21.400
foray into this, get out there and
make sales happen.

906
00:44:21.400 --> 00:44:26.530
Understand what it takes for a sales
cycle because guess what tech is only 5%.

907
00:44:26.530 --> 00:44:30.071
Okay you have to bring in revenue
you have to bring in sales

908
00:44:30.071 --> 00:44:31.082
>> Absolutely

909
00:44:31.082 --> 00:44:32.545
>> And at the end of the day it is

910
00:44:32.545 --> 00:44:33.190
what it is.

911
00:44:33.190 --> 00:44:36.875
What you make of your business is
what you make of your business but

912
00:44:36.875 --> 00:44:39.680
we're always here to be
able to offer advice.

913
00:44:39.680 --> 00:44:44.160
So if you need advice or you have an idea
or something that you want to pass

914
00:44:44.160 --> 00:44:47.880
by us for a sniff test,
we're always willing to hear it.

915
00:44:47.880 --> 00:44:48.970
You can hit us up.

916
00:44:48.970 --> 00:44:53.920
You can find me on Twitter
@csp3r also known as Casper or

917
00:44:53.920 --> 00:44:57.460
here's my email address Slyons@redlion.io.

918
00:44:57.460 --> 00:44:59.852
And I'm Josh Marpet,
you can find me @quadling on twitter,

919
00:44:59.852 --> 00:45:02.529
I’m only occasionally on it,
probably better to hit me up on email.

920
00:45:02.529 --> 00:45:06.489
Jmarpet@redlion.io and
thank you for tuning in for

921
00:45:06.489 --> 00:45:11.710
watching this episode of business for

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.055
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.055 --> 00:00:10.213
Hi, and thanks for joining us at
BIZPRO.TV for the business for

3
00:00:10.213 --> 00:00:14.850
technology series of talks done by
Scott Lions and Josh Marpet myself.

4
00:00:14.850 --> 00:00:18.050
We're from Red Lion and we are here to
talk to you about product creation today.

5
00:00:18.050 --> 00:00:20.870
So Scott, why don't we start
off by telling us about you.

6
00:00:20.870 --> 00:00:22.580
>> Sure thing, thanks Josh.

7
00:00:22.580 --> 00:00:26.540
So hi, I'm Scott Lyons,
I am the CEO of Red Lion.

8
00:00:26.540 --> 00:00:31.380
I am a graduate of the school of
hard knocks as far as business goes.

9
00:00:31.380 --> 00:00:35.770
I've been all over the IT industry
from government to commercial.

10
00:00:35.770 --> 00:00:38.620
I have assisted in multiple events.

11
00:00:38.620 --> 00:00:40.390
I'm a certification holder.

12
00:00:40.390 --> 00:00:41.790
I won't say which ones though.

13
00:00:41.790 --> 00:00:44.270
And my passions really are people and
business.

14
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:44.770
Josh.

15
00:00:46.210 --> 00:00:47.736
>> Hi, I'm Josh Marpet.

16
00:00:47.736 --> 00:00:49.060
I'm the COO of Red Lion.

17
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:51.990
I've been a speaker at so
many conferences,

18
00:00:51.990 --> 00:00:53.960
I literally don't remember anymore.

19
00:00:53.960 --> 00:00:57.320
I'm a member of the CEO organizations,
Mindshare and Missionlink.

20
00:00:57.320 --> 00:00:59.080
I've been around the block more than once.

21
00:00:59.080 --> 00:01:00.310
I was a board member of Hackers for

22
00:01:00.310 --> 00:01:04.610
Charity besides Las Vegas,
Cloud Security Alliance Delaware Valley.

23
00:01:04.610 --> 00:01:08.030
We're starting up a journal of
information security called SYNACK.

24
00:01:08.030 --> 00:01:12.600
I run besides Delaware and
occasionally I get to nap once in a while.

25
00:01:12.600 --> 00:01:13.450
>> Napping is important.

26
00:01:13.450 --> 00:01:14.770
And you know what's also important?

27
00:01:14.770 --> 00:01:16.449
Product creation okay?

28
00:01:16.449 --> 00:01:19.900
And that's really what we're
talking about in today's talk.

29
00:01:19.900 --> 00:01:27.000
We are moving into the steps of
what it takes for making a product.

30
00:01:28.820 --> 00:01:30.510
>> So what are those steps?

31
00:01:30.510 --> 00:01:35.230
Well, it ranges from where are you
now to where do I go from here?

32
00:01:35.230 --> 00:01:37.420
How do I fund it?
What are the different stages?

33
00:01:37.420 --> 00:01:38.390
How do I pay for it?

34
00:01:38.390 --> 00:01:41.420
All these different steps,
not necessarily in this order, but

35
00:01:41.420 --> 00:01:44.300
this is the way we just organize it to
make it simple to go through, okay?

36
00:01:44.300 --> 00:01:47.190
So don't take this as Gospel
in terms of the order.

37
00:01:47.190 --> 00:01:48.673
But let's start with where am I now.

38
00:01:48.673 --> 00:01:53.490
If you've got a product, I have
an idea but I haven't built anything.

39
00:01:54.530 --> 00:01:57.960
I've built a prototype or
I actually have some customers.

40
00:01:57.960 --> 00:02:01.901
So those are sort of the three
defining moments in product creation.

41
00:02:01.901 --> 00:02:03.547
All right, and if you have an idea.

42
00:02:03.547 --> 00:02:07.146
You know this because, I've got
something a solution for a problem,

43
00:02:07.146 --> 00:02:11.200
I've got a problem that, that problem
a lot of people have that problem.

44
00:02:11.200 --> 00:02:14.790
They have money they're
currently spending, and hey.

45
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:15.860
I've got a better solution.

46
00:02:16.860 --> 00:02:19.430
>> Right, but
have you really built a prototype?

47
00:02:19.430 --> 00:02:20.280
Okay?

48
00:02:20.280 --> 00:02:21.830
Was it simple to build?

49
00:02:21.830 --> 00:02:23.130
Does it actually work?

50
00:02:24.400 --> 00:02:26.780
That's a real big problem
that we're seeing.

51
00:02:26.780 --> 00:02:32.720
People build prototypes, and they build
it for just one aspect of the problem.

52
00:02:33.790 --> 00:02:37.770
So does your prototype actually fit it?

53
00:02:37.770 --> 00:02:41.990
And what are your customers saying,
are they paying for the solution?

54
00:02:43.290 --> 00:02:44.640
Are you post revenue right?

55
00:02:44.640 --> 00:02:49.483
So, does it mean that you have put out
enough prototypes to be able to say

56
00:02:49.483 --> 00:02:51.036
yes I have customers.

57
00:02:51.036 --> 00:02:53.711
>> Well it's not necessarily putting
out the number of prototypes,

58
00:02:53.711 --> 00:02:55.250
it's how many customers do you have?

59
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:57.163
>> Yeah
>> So again, that third stage is,

60
00:02:57.163 --> 00:03:01.441
I had an idea, I built a prototype and
now I've got somebody to pay for me,

61
00:03:01.441 --> 00:03:06.510
paid me for that prototype, which is
amazing because then you're post revenue.

62
00:03:06.510 --> 00:03:07.876
Post revenue is a term of art
>> Yep.

63
00:03:07.876 --> 00:03:09.350
>> Adventure capitalists use it a lot.

64
00:03:09.350 --> 00:03:12.104
It means somebody has started
giving me money to use my product,

65
00:03:12.104 --> 00:03:14.052
which is a wonderful stage
to be at by the way.

66
00:03:14.052 --> 00:03:16.232
>> But what about validation?

67
00:03:16.232 --> 00:03:18.770
>> Okay, so validation is important.

68
00:03:18.770 --> 00:03:21.470
If you don't have validation,
you've got a problem.

69
00:03:21.470 --> 00:03:23.310
Now look this is an interesting one.

70
00:03:23.310 --> 00:03:27.770
So Juicero, if you've heard about them,
they spent $120 million

71
00:03:27.770 --> 00:03:32.640
to build an incredibly complex supply
chain and a beautifully engineered product

72
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:37.600
that you could replicate with a pair
of hands around one of their pouches.

73
00:03:37.600 --> 00:03:39.680
>> Yep.
>> If you didn't hear about them it was

74
00:03:39.680 --> 00:03:44.850
a $400 juice machine that you had to
use their pouches to get juice out of.

75
00:03:44.850 --> 00:03:48.060
Each pouch gave you, I think one
glass of juice and cost about four or

76
00:03:48.060 --> 00:03:51.380
five dollars, which means that I could
have gone down to my local barista,

77
00:03:51.380 --> 00:03:54.940
and smoothie shop and got one for
roughly the same price.

78
00:03:54.940 --> 00:03:59.100
But the only reason that you get
a Juicero was, it looks cool.

79
00:03:59.100 --> 00:04:02.480
Needless to say Juicero is out of
business, that’s just ridiculous.

80
00:04:02.480 --> 00:04:03.810
They didn’t validate properly.

81
00:04:03.810 --> 00:04:09.020
>> Yeah and the product that they had
is absolutely beautifully engineered.

82
00:04:09.020 --> 00:04:14.850
If you go to the address that is here and
you look at how the system breaks apart,

83
00:04:14.850 --> 00:04:16.990
you'll see what we're saying.

84
00:04:16.990 --> 00:04:20.900
>> They had complex castings,
massive amounts of engineering

85
00:04:20.900 --> 00:04:25.630
that went into an amazing juice press
That was totally useless and a failure,

86
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:28.290
but really cool engineering.

87
00:04:28.290 --> 00:04:29.510
That's a problem, people.

88
00:04:29.510 --> 00:04:31.500
They didn't go out there.

89
00:04:31.500 --> 00:04:33.120
They didn't build prototype one.

90
00:04:33.120 --> 00:04:34.800
They didn't say hey, do you like it?

91
00:04:34.800 --> 00:04:36.020
Then they build prototype two.

92
00:04:36.020 --> 00:04:37.400
Do you like it even more?

93
00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:38.490
Hey, build prototype three.

94
00:04:38.490 --> 00:04:41.130
Let's iterate through the solutions.

95
00:04:41.130 --> 00:04:44.709
So, let's talk about those types of
things you can do, the iterations.

96
00:04:45.970 --> 00:04:50.180
So if you've got an idea,
you need to validate the idea.

97
00:04:50.180 --> 00:04:51.590
Who has the problem?

98
00:04:51.590 --> 00:04:52.910
Are there enough people?

99
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:53.990
Do they need a solution?

100
00:04:53.990 --> 00:04:54.690
Do they even care?

101
00:04:54.690 --> 00:04:56.130
They might have the problem,
and it might be so

102
00:04:56.130 --> 00:04:59.410
miniscule, they just don't care, okay?

103
00:04:59.410 --> 00:05:00.810
Would they use your solution?

104
00:05:00.810 --> 00:05:03.510
Hey, look at my product,
would you use this?

105
00:05:05.130 --> 00:05:06.160
That's pretty cool.

106
00:05:06.160 --> 00:05:07.290
That's validation.

107
00:05:07.290 --> 00:05:08.060
Okay?

108
00:05:08.060 --> 00:05:09.450
Would you pay for it?

109
00:05:09.450 --> 00:05:12.150
Yeah.
I'd give you $1,000 a month for

110
00:05:12.150 --> 00:05:13.200
that product.

111
00:05:13.200 --> 00:05:13.980
Great.

112
00:05:13.980 --> 00:05:17.930
Would you mind signing a check for
$1,000 for your first month's bill?

113
00:05:17.930 --> 00:05:21.890
And obviously you know, you wont
get a product for three months, but

114
00:05:21.890 --> 00:05:23.550
you'll be the first to get it.

115
00:05:23.550 --> 00:05:25.070
Has anybody heard of Kickstarter?

116
00:05:25.070 --> 00:05:28.490
>> Right, and it's funny that you'd
say that because that really goes into

117
00:05:28.490 --> 00:05:32.190
determining how much funding you
actually need for your prototype.

118
00:05:32.190 --> 00:05:34.410
So, how much is the code?

119
00:05:34.410 --> 00:05:36.190
How much is the hardware?

120
00:05:36.190 --> 00:05:38.460
How much in cloud assets,
are you using the cloud?

121
00:05:38.460 --> 00:05:41.995
Do you need the cloud because the cloud
is really somebody else's computer,okay.

122
00:05:43.170 --> 00:05:44.880
How many people do you
need to back this up?

123
00:05:44.880 --> 00:05:47.417
What does your UI UX look like?

124
00:05:47.417 --> 00:05:50.925
And then you double and
triple that amount because, let's face it,

125
00:05:50.925 --> 00:05:53.805
a lot of people just don't
get the estimation correct.

126
00:05:53.805 --> 00:05:56.388
[LAUGH]
>> Estimates are tough, man,

127
00:05:56.388 --> 00:05:57.760
estimates are tough.

128
00:05:57.760 --> 00:06:00.390
It's gonna take a developer
like three days.

129
00:06:00.390 --> 00:06:01.560
And when you get a developer and they go,

130
00:06:01.560 --> 00:06:04.570
it's gonna take two weeks, you just
blew your estimate out of the water.

131
00:06:04.570 --> 00:06:07.410
>> Right, but
you know what's more difficult?

132
00:06:07.410 --> 00:06:10.760
Getting somebody to actually write
the check, stroke the check.

133
00:06:12.380 --> 00:06:14.380
>> Dear God, that's not a joke.

134
00:06:14.380 --> 00:06:17.474
I remember that the first people you
normally get checks from are the three F,

135
00:06:17.474 --> 00:06:19.246
and that's family, friends, and fools.

136
00:06:19.246 --> 00:06:22.570
And that's actually a term of art,
it's not a joke.

137
00:06:22.570 --> 00:06:26.510
That's the first round of funding,
family, friends, and fools.

138
00:06:26.510 --> 00:06:28.590
And if you can get money from them, great.

139
00:06:28.590 --> 00:06:30.440
I prefer to get it from
perspective customers.

140
00:06:30.440 --> 00:06:33.020
I prefer to give them a prototype,
show them an idea, and

141
00:06:33.020 --> 00:06:34.320
say would you sign a check?

142
00:06:34.320 --> 00:06:37.710
Because let's be honest, if they're
willing to put a check out there right now

143
00:06:37.710 --> 00:06:41.046
for that idea, that means your idea is
that good that they're that excited and

144
00:06:41.046 --> 00:06:42.839
that to me is the perfect form of funding.

145
00:06:42.839 --> 00:06:46.020
That's what Kickstart and GoFundMe and

Embrace the failure and learn from it.

374
00:17:43.941 --> 00:17:47.840
Don't just assume that, my, it's
a failure, I'm gonna run to the hills.

375
00:17:47.840 --> 00:17:49.460
No, it's like come on learn from it,

376
00:17:49.460 --> 00:17:51.802
because that's how you
succeed in later iterations.

377
00:17:51.802 --> 00:17:55.419
Whether it's an iteration of this company,
whether it's an iteration of your life,

378
00:17:55.419 --> 00:17:57.361
whatever it is,
you're gonna learn from it.

379
00:17:57.361 --> 00:17:59.839
If you fail to learn from it,
you're doomed to repeat it.

380
00:17:59.839 --> 00:18:04.986
>> Okay, so speaking of failure, one of

00:18:15.163 --> 00:18:19.390
Number two, as far as red lining goes,

00:18:19.390 --> 00:18:23.550
So we win, you win,

So when you're going through deals and

>> Well, this goes back to

00:18:40.432 --> 00:18:43.600

00:18:43.600 --> 00:18:48.581

Wait, you're an entrepeneur,

00:18:57.686 --> 00:19:00.616

again rather than their rack rate, okay?

00:19:00.616 --> 00:19:02.723
Trust me on that.

Invite people to barbeques.

401

Well rack rate,

>> B51-
>> Okay, yeah.

The rack rate is the actual
normal rate of the product.

00:19:15.443 --> 00:19:20.135
So in a lawyer, if they're rack rate is

00:19:20.135 --> 00:19:24.642
scotch, you got a significant discount,

00:19:24.642 --> 00:19:27.046

00:19:29.580 --> 00:19:32.360

00:19:34.854 --> 00:19:37.388

00:19:37.388 --> 00:19:40.701

that you're iterating your business,

00:19:40.701 --> 00:19:43.603

you're moving things along, okay?

00:19:43.603 --> 00:19:46.040

415
00:19:46.040 --> 00:19:50.270

416
00:19:50.270 --> 00:19:50.796
>> Absolutely.

00:19:50.796 --> 00:19:52.220
Now what's an MVP?

418
00:19:52.220 --> 00:19:53.700
What's minimum viable product?

419
00:19:53.700 --> 00:19:55.530
This is part of product creation.

420
00:19:55.530 --> 00:19:59.495
An MVP is your minimum viable product,
what you can build that you will sell,

421
00:19:59.495 --> 00:20:02.484
not what you can build that's
a piece of what you can sell,

422
00:20:02.484 --> 00:20:04.267
what you can build that will sell.

423
00:20:04.267 --> 00:20:09.030
And I love this illustration,

00:20:09.030 --> 00:20:12.479

00:20:12.479 --> 00:20:13.811
I'm gonna build a skateboard.

426
00:20:13.811 --> 00:20:16.501
Rather than build two wheels connected
by a frame, who's gonna buy that?

427
00:20:16.501 --> 00:20:18.023
Somebody that's gonna
push it down the hill?

428
00:20:18.023 --> 00:20:21.395
Come on,
I'm gonna build a razor scooter, okay?

429
00:20:21.395 --> 00:20:27.110
At every stage that you sell a product,

430
00:20:27.110 --> 00:20:30.170
Every company that I know of that's
successful, pivots, iterates,

431
00:20:30.170 --> 00:20:31.195

432
00:20:31.195 --> 00:20:33.799

they add on another channel,

00:20:33.799 --> 00:20:35.004
they add on another piece.

434

Look, we're doing this talk at BizPro.TV,

00:20:37.881 --> 00:20:40.432
which is an iteration of ITPro.TV
>> Yeah.

That is a movement forward,
that is a building on another piece, and

00:20:46.114 --> 00:20:48.650
that's the right way to do things.

439
00:20:48.650 --> 00:20:50.199
>> Okay, so I have this MVP.

440
00:20:50.199 --> 00:20:52.653
My real question is how do I pay for

441
00:20:52.653 --> 00:20:57.321
So what I'm looking to do as a CEO is say,

00:20:57.321 --> 00:21:01.520
mortgage, beg, borrow, but

444
00:21:04.200 --> 00:21:08.216
Your friends and family are investors,
if the idea's infectious enough and

00:21:08.216 --> 00:21:09.647

446
00:21:09.647 --> 00:21:13.961
Your day job, okay, keep that until
you're ready, but realistically,

447
00:21:13.961 --> 00:21:15.476
who needs sleep, right?

448
00:21:15.476 --> 00:21:22.407
When we're talking about putting things
on beg, borrow and credit cards, right?

449
00:21:22.407 --> 00:21:25.443
If you have a contract,
more than likely most banks,

450
00:21:25.443 --> 00:21:27.810
if you take them a contract and say, yes.

451
00:21:27.810 --> 00:21:32.263
They have signed for this many units the
bank will actually work with you to give

452
00:21:32.263 --> 00:21:34.835
you a loan against what
the contract states.

453
00:21:34.835 --> 00:21:37.913
>> Now be careful because if they
break the contract, you've just lost

454
00:21:37.913 --> 00:21:41.710
the collateral for your loan and
the bank's gonna call it right now.

455
00:21:41.710 --> 00:21:44.990
So make sure that you have an iron
clad contract with penalties and

456
00:21:44.990 --> 00:21:46.300
things like that.

457
00:21:46.300 --> 00:21:49.395
Do whatever you can to make sure that
they can't break that contract and

458
00:21:49.395 --> 00:21:51.365
that they absolutely adore you, all right?

459
00:21:51.365 --> 00:21:56.420
Keep your day job until you have somewhere
where you can stand fairly well secure.

460
00:21:56.420 --> 00:21:59.791
If you have to remortgage your house to do
something that you're not 100% sure of,

461
00:21:59.791 --> 00:22:02.206
I'd have a real problem signing

462
00:22:02.206 --> 00:22:02.821
>> Okay.

463
00:22:02.821 --> 00:22:03.726
>> Be careful please.

00:22:03.726 --> 00:22:09.030
>> So I don't mean to cut you off here,

gonna drive us completely not being in

Of product creation with the seven

00:22:24.067 --> 00:22:28.623

00:22:28.623 --> 00:22:32.790
And first you start off with the proble,
.I can't do this, I need a solution.

entrepreneurs start with the problem

Whether it's something in their job
workflow, whether it's a problem at work,

The guy who came up with the hot dog bun

Because he'd never cooked hot dogs or

>> Yeah.
>> He had a problem,

478
00:22:51.078 --> 00:22:53.640

to fix that problem.

00:22:53.640 --> 00:22:56.213
So he said, I've got a problem,

00:22:56.213 --> 00:22:58.088

Does anybody else have this problem?

So there's a lot of ingredients

00:23:44.571 --> 00:23:48.588

00:23:52.459 --> 00:23:53.305

What features are you gonna be adding?

What pieces?

00:23:56.404 --> 00:23:56.958

00:23:56.958 --> 00:23:57.617
What functions?

00:23:57.617 --> 00:23:58.780

00:23:58.780 --> 00:24:01.540
Are you gonna be adding on to your product
to make it even better down the road?

00:24:01.540 --> 00:24:03.422
That's why they call it a roadmap.

509
00:24:03.422 --> 00:24:07.368
All of these matter in terms of building a

510
00:24:07.368 --> 00:24:12.280
In terms of getting your product from
I have a problem to I have successful

511
00:24:12.280 --> 00:24:13.900
business, okay?

512
00:24:13.900 --> 00:24:19.150
And if you're not paying attention to

00:24:19.150 --> 00:24:22.211

00:26:04.860 --> 00:26:07.010
A vertical is an industry, okay?

528

A horizontal is how big.

529
00:26:08.480 --> 00:26:11.890
In aerospace, you've got everything
from little tiny companies.

That are making one part for Space X's,
Falcon 9's, let's say, and at

531

532
00:26:23.320 --> 00:26:27.430
They're monstrous companies, so
the horizontal is the size of the company.

533
00:26:27.430 --> 00:26:30.340
But both of those companies as you
mentioned are in the same vertical

534
00:26:30.340 --> 00:26:30.909
aerospace.

535
00:26:30.909 --> 00:26:31.880
Does that make sense?

536
00:26:31.880 --> 00:26:35.510

the question, who is your best client?

537
00:26:35.510 --> 00:26:36.460

538
00:26:36.460 --> 00:26:37.520
Do you wanna go after small?

539
00:26:37.520 --> 00:26:39.540
Do you wanna go after government or
commercial?

540
00:26:39.540 --> 00:26:45.360
I know, personally for Red Lion, we like
to have a pipeline of a couple of larges,

541
00:26:45.360 --> 00:26:48.510
couple of mediums, and
a whole bunch of smalls.

542
00:26:48.510 --> 00:26:53.460
So realistically,
what we're trying to say is it gives us

543
00:26:53.460 --> 00:26:56.210
the runway to be able to
get to the bigger projects.

544
00:26:56.210 --> 00:26:57.900
>> And the flexibility,
absolutely correct.

545
00:26:57.900 --> 00:27:01.070
>> Yeah, yeah,
because you need to be able to pivot and

00:27:01.070 --> 00:27:05.010

547
00:27:05.010 --> 00:27:06.950
So, the question is,

548
00:27:06.950 --> 00:27:09.780

00:27:11.830 --> 00:27:16.600

your community, or your local government,

00:27:16.600 --> 00:27:18.740

551
00:27:18.740 --> 00:27:23.080

00:27:26.270 --> 00:27:27.700

>> Meet them at an association,

00:27:29.240 --> 00:27:30.790

Meet them over a bagel

Ron Schmeltzer, I meet so

00:27:41.868 --> 00:27:44.720

00:27:45.410 --> 00:27:48.180

00:27:53.500 --> 00:27:55.350
Figure out who you want to meet,

00:28:25.470 --> 00:28:27.770

00:28:40.720 --> 00:28:42.620

know don't bother any more,

582
00:28:42.620 --> 00:28:44.230
don't bother me anymore I

583
00:28:44.230 --> 00:28:48.115
Okay thank you, I'm sorry to have bothered
you, I'll move onto the next company,

584
00:28:48.115 --> 00:28:49.331
there's plenty of them.

585
00:28:49.331 --> 00:28:53.283
It's okay, alright and
remember you may not know somebody,

586
00:28:53.283 --> 00:28:56.310
I really want to get at this one person.

587
00:28:56.310 --> 00:28:58.080
Start asking your friends and your family.

588
00:28:58.080 --> 00:29:00.345
Does anybody know anybody who's

589
00:29:00.345 --> 00:29:01.780
>> Mm-hm.
>> You'd be shocked

00:29:01.780 --> 00:29:03.550
how many people you're connected to.

591
00:29:03.550 --> 00:29:06.060
Remember six degrees of separation, is it?

592
00:29:06.060 --> 00:29:07.590
>> Six degrees of Kevin Bacon.

593
00:29:07.590 --> 00:29:10.210
>> So, well, okay, but
it starts with six degrees of separation.

594
00:29:10.210 --> 00:29:12.950
If you wanna get to Kevin Bacon,

595
00:29:12.950 --> 00:29:14.980
He's not important to me
in terms of business.

596
00:29:14.980 --> 00:29:18.320
I'm sorry, Kevin, I apologize,
you can feel free to yell at me.

597
00:29:18.320 --> 00:29:21.860
But in terms of business, six degrees
of separation, you'd be shocked

598
00:29:21.860 --> 00:29:25.510

599
00:29:25.510 --> 00:29:29.040
>> Right, and
that's a really great parlay, if you will,

00:29:33.650 --> 00:29:37.080

really think they come from the stork,

00:29:37.080 --> 00:29:38.870
they just fall out of the sky.

603
00:29:38.870 --> 00:29:40.950
No, they don't okay.

604
00:29:40.950 --> 00:29:43.750
Sales come from cultivation of leads.

605
00:29:43.750 --> 00:29:49.710
They come from the most unexpected places,
friends, family, connections.

606
00:29:49.710 --> 00:29:52.110
Hey, I know a guy who needs this done,

607
00:29:52.110 --> 00:29:56.560
we've had some of our most lucrative
contracts so far happen in that nature.

608
00:29:56.560 --> 00:29:58.030
>> Absolutely, absolutely.

609
00:29:58.030 --> 00:30:02.410
So look, it matters in terms of how
long does a sale like would take.

610
00:30:02.410 --> 00:30:06.220
If you're selling with the government,
the sale cycle by the is 18 to 36 months.

611
00:30:06.220 --> 00:30:10.643
If you're selling to a company the bigger
ones the sale cycle is 6 to 12 months.

612
00:30:10.643 --> 00:30:12.860
The smaller ones it could
be little as three days.

613
00:30:12.860 --> 00:30:16.910
We've made a sale for in under two
hours based on we've met somebody.

614
00:30:16.910 --> 00:30:20.710
They liked what we've talked about and we
we're even realizing they wanted to buy.

615
00:30:20.710 --> 00:30:23.030
But they realized that they
needed something we had.

616
00:30:23.030 --> 00:30:24.250
They said, do you sell this?

617
00:30:24.250 --> 00:30:25.760
Can you do this for us?

618
00:30:25.760 --> 00:30:26.790
Well yeah, what do you need?

619
00:30:26.790 --> 00:30:28.360
We need this, we'll charge you this.

620
00:30:28.360 --> 00:30:30.140
Okay, here's a check.

621
00:30:30.140 --> 00:30:32.290
My God, this is wonderful.

622
00:30:32.290 --> 00:30:34.862
So you've gotta know how
long your sales cycle take.

623
00:30:34.862 --> 00:30:36.290
You gotta know what's
gonna get in your way.

624
00:30:36.290 --> 00:30:37.029
What's that called, Scott?

625
00:30:38.080 --> 00:30:39.444
>> Friction, sales friction.

626
00:30:39.444 --> 00:30:40.140
>> Lots and lots of friction.

627
00:30:40.140 --> 00:30:42.460
>> But, you have to understand though,
Josh and

00:30:42.460 --> 00:30:46.030

00:30:46.030 --> 00:30:50.420

630
00:30:50.420 --> 00:30:52.970
To know where business is going to head.

We can always watch talks on irongeek.com,

00:30:56.280 --> 00:30:59.570
Adrian Crenshaw shout out,

00:30:59.570 --> 00:31:02.530
We can go there and
see anything at anytime but

00:31:02.530 --> 00:31:06.590
what we don't have access

00:31:06.590 --> 00:31:08.920
That's really where we pour
our resources into and

636
00:31:08.920 --> 00:31:11.080
that gets us the business development.

637
00:31:11.080 --> 00:31:14.820
>> Absolutely, and there's also people
that we don't wanna talk to at all if we

638
00:31:14.820 --> 00:31:16.500
can avoid and that's legal.

639
00:31:16.500 --> 00:31:18.180
Don't get me wrong, I love lawyers but,

640
00:31:18.180 --> 00:31:20.440
they're the slowest thing
in the contract cycle.

641
00:31:20.440 --> 00:31:23.850
So the faster you can get through legal
by having pre cleared look documents that

642
00:31:23.850 --> 00:31:26.570
have been pre cleared by someone very
prominent in the legal industry.

643
00:31:29.350 --> 00:31:32.516
Have certifications on your security; have
certifications on your cyber insurance,

644
00:31:32.516 --> 00:31:33.520
add everything pre-done.

645
00:31:33.520 --> 00:31:34.663
The faster you get through legal,

646
00:31:34.663 --> 00:31:36.792
the faster you're gonna get
through the contract sales cycle,

647
00:31:36.792 --> 00:31:38.580
the faster you can get that
magic thing called money.

648
00:31:38.580 --> 00:31:41.390
I know its an amazing concept,
but basically,

649
00:31:41.390 --> 00:31:45.758
everything that stops you is sales
friction, legalist sales friction.

650
00:31:45.758 --> 00:31:48.405
That's why we work very hard
to get certifications done,

651
00:31:48.405 --> 00:31:51.171
we get all the documents pre-cleared and
so on and so forth.

652
00:31:51.171 --> 00:31:53.917
Because remember,
even after you've gotten through legal,

653
00:31:53.917 --> 00:31:57.021
you can still hear the worst thing
you can possibly hear, which is hey,

00:31:57.021 --> 00:32:00.870
we should talk about this in a couple of
months when we get some more budget news.

655
00:32:00.870 --> 00:32:05.840
But all the work you've done so far,
let's just shelve it for six months, okay?

656
00:32:05.840 --> 00:32:08.590
>> And to be honest,
that's a very viable option.

657
00:32:08.590 --> 00:32:10.690
It's known as the entrepreneur
rollercoaster.

658
00:32:12.170 --> 00:32:15.290
Where you get money one day and
hey, everybody eats steak,

659
00:32:15.290 --> 00:32:16.710
the next day everybody eats ramen.

660
00:32:16.710 --> 00:32:19.740
The next day everybody eats steak,
the next day everybody eats ramen.

661
00:32:19.740 --> 00:32:22.047
You go from high to low,
to high to low, and

662
00:32:22.047 --> 00:32:24.176
good to bad to good to bad to good to bad.

663
00:32:24.176 --> 00:32:27.881
And somewhere in there, you figure out
where the pivot is to really start

664
00:32:27.881 --> 00:32:30.876
smoothing out the good and
the bad to get it nice and level.

665
00:32:30.876 --> 00:32:31.550
>> No, no.

666
00:32:31.550 --> 00:32:34.585
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think the entrepreneur's

667
00:32:34.585 --> 00:32:38.130
rollercoaster smooths out because

00:32:38.130 --> 00:32:40.441
And you start realizing that

669
00:32:40.441 --> 00:32:41.060
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

00:32:41.060 --> 00:32:42.310
>> I'll be honest with you.

671
00:32:42.310 --> 00:32:43.790
But it's-
>> Stress and no sleep.

00:32:43.790 --> 00:32:45.270
>> It's tough, it's very tough.

00:32:45.270 --> 00:32:48.280

00:32:54.918 --> 00:32:58.750

00:32:58.750 --> 00:33:02.170

00:33:02.170 --> 00:33:05.520

00:33:05.520 --> 00:33:08.350
customers, clients,
people that you can call on and

00:33:08.350 --> 00:33:10.220

00:33:10.220 --> 00:33:13.658
>> Yeah, and you have to network

00:33:13.658 --> 00:33:16.060

00:33:16.060 --> 00:33:19.850

00:33:19.850 --> 00:33:21.090

00:33:21.090 --> 00:33:23.850
It's not that easy, okay?

00:33:23.850 --> 00:33:26.370

00:33:26.370 --> 00:33:29.660

00:33:29.660 --> 00:33:33.417

00:33:33.417 --> 00:33:34.301

00:33:34.301 --> 00:33:37.897

693
00:33:41.190 --> 00:33:44.870

694
00:33:44.870 --> 00:33:48.300
It's very difficult and that's part

695
00:33:48.300 --> 00:33:50.500
In a consulting business,
you eat what you kill.

696
00:33:50.500 --> 00:33:53.460
Whatever you bring in, you eat it.

697
00:33:53.460 --> 00:33:57.650
In a business, not just an occupation but
a business, you kill something,

00:34:00.100 --> 00:34:03.030
The idea is to get everybody so
efficient, working so

00:34:03.030 --> 00:34:06.830
hard, getting things done,
that we bring in more than we need today,

701
00:34:06.830 --> 00:34:09.000
more than we need tomorrow,
more than we need next week.

702
00:34:09.000 --> 00:34:10.980
So that we accrue value and

703
00:34:10.980 --> 00:34:15.310

or people with fat bank accounts.

704
00:34:15.310 --> 00:34:16.170
We're okay with either.

705
00:34:16.170 --> 00:34:20.280
>> Yeah, so a lot of it can be akin to

00:34:20.280 --> 00:34:24.525

>> Yeah.
>> Okay, you're not gonna get a chance to

00:34:28.265 --> 00:34:31.395

00:34:31.395 --> 00:34:36.995
Bears, they hibernate, so your source

711
00:34:36.995 --> 00:34:39.525
So you need to be able to be prepared for
a rainy day.

712
00:34:40.890 --> 00:34:45.560
>> So basically, doing business
development is very, very tough.

00:34:45.560 --> 00:34:47.380
It's something you've gotta network on.

00:34:47.380 --> 00:34:49.120
It's something you've

00:34:49.120 --> 00:34:50.855
And remember, a lot of technologists,

00:34:50.855 --> 00:34:53.003

00:34:58.580 --> 00:35:00.110

00:35:00.110 --> 00:35:01.960

00:35:01.960 --> 00:35:03.247
You've gotta go network,

722
00:35:03.247 --> 00:35:05.644
And if you're not good at it,
hire somebody who is,

723
00:35:05.644 --> 00:35:08.050

get somebody who is.

724
00:35:08.050 --> 00:35:10.680

00:35:10.680 --> 00:35:14.210
the network, has the network, has the
friends, the family, the whatever to help

00:35:14.210 --> 00:35:17.920

727
00:35:17.920 --> 00:35:21.790
And so business development is all about,
strangely enough, not technology.

728
00:35:21.790 --> 00:35:23.120
It's really all about people.

729
00:35:23.120 --> 00:35:25.350
>> It's about the relationships
that you have, and

730
00:35:25.350 --> 00:35:29.470
